metadata.name: The Valluvar
metadata.description:
The Valluvar Statue in Kanyakumari is a symbol of the great poet-saint Thiruvalluvar and his contribution to Tamil literature and philosophy. Situated at the confluence of the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean, it stands at 133 feet, making it one of the tallest statues in India. 

Thiruvalluvarholding a book in one hand and making a gesture of blessing with the other. Here are the meanings behind these symbols and what they represent in the context of Thiruvalluvar's teachings and Tamil culture:

The Book: Thiruvalluvar is holding a book in one hand, which represents his most famous literary work, the Thirukkural. The Thirukkural is a collection of 1,330 couplets that cover a wide range of topics, including ethics, love, governance, and wealth. It is considered to be one of the most important works of Tamil literature and is still widely read and studied today. Thiruvalluvar's emphasis on ethics and morality in the Thirukkural has made him a revered figure in Tamil culture.
